awd_titl_txt: Discovery and study of spin-orbit-coupled quantum materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract: 
Condensed matter research has produced many novel materials with fundamental properties that underpin a remarkable number of cutting-edge technologies. It is now generally accepted that novel materials are necessary for critical advances in technologies and whoever discovers novel materials generally controls the science and technology of the future. The 4d- and 5d- transition metal elements constitute two thirds of the d-transition metal elements listed in the Periodic Table. However, these materials have remained largely unexplored. This project presents a systematic effort to discover, investigate and control novel quantum states in 4d/5d materials. A delicate balance between spin-orbit and other competing interactions inherent in these materials offers a unique range of opportunities to uncover and control exotic states and physical properties.  This project also provides rigorous training to all students involved, focusing on synthesis and characterization techniques covering a broad spectrum of materials and experimental probes available in the principal investigator's laboratory. 

Technical Abstract: 
Physics driven by spin-orbit interactions is among the most important topics in contemporary condensed matter physics. This project is driven by Two Interconnected Thrusts - Discovery of New Quantum Materials and Control of Novel Quantum States. Thrust One: The PI targets three Subgroups of 4d/5d materials for single-crystal synthesis and study: 1. Oxides, 2. S- and Se-based chalcogenides and 3. Tellurides. The underlying behavior of these subgroups is expected to systematically evolve from more correlated, insulating states (oxides) to more spin-orbit-coupled, metallic states (tellurides) via a crossover regime dictated by complex structures (S or Se chalcogenides). This key trend provides unique circumstances to effectively tune the relative strength of correlations and spin-orbit interactions (SOI) in order to uncover/control exotic states in an unprecedented fashion. Thrust Two: The SOI exhibits particularly strong and surprising influence on the physical properties of the 4d/5d materials, in which a key characteristic is that the SOI can rigidly lock magnetic moments to the lattice, leading to novel behavior.  The PI investigates lattice-control physical properties of spin-orbit-coupled materials via application of electrical current, hydrostatic pressure, or chemical doping. Electrical-current control of structural and physical properties is a long-sought, but elusive goal of contemporary science and technology. The PI's recent discovery demonstrates that a combination of strong SOI and a canted antiferromagnetic Mott state is sufficient to attain this important goal. The Nation is committed to a quantum revolution but is poorly supported by the lack of scientists who are experienced in quantum materials discovery and synthesis. This project is well-timed to address this problem via rigorous graduate training emphasizing materials discovery and synthesis and providing high-quality crystals of novel materials for extensive collaborations, which is necessary to advance our collective understanding of the novel phenomena under study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It is widely recognized that whoever controls materials controls technology. Novel quantum materials, which often exhibit surprising or even revolutionary physical properties, are necessary for critical advances in technologies that affect the everyday lives of people.

Transition metal elements constitute a major portion of the most important elements listed in the Periodic Table, however, many quantum materials containing these elements have remained largely unexplored. The project supported by this award has uncovered a wealth of new quantum states of matter, which is of both fundamental and technological significance.

For example, colossal magnetoresistance is an extraordinary enhancement of the electric conductivity in the presence of a magnetic field. It is conventionally associated with a spin polarization, which drastically reduces electric resistance. But the study led by the principal investigator (PI) recently revealed an intriguing exception to this conventional wisdom, indicating a novel quantum state. The quantum material in question is Mn3Si2Te6, a “honeycomb” where manganese and tellurium atoms form a network of interlocking octahedra that look like the cells in a beehive. The honeycomb didn’t not allow electric currents to pass through it easily.  When the honeycomb is exposed to magnetic fields in a certain way, however, it suddenly became millions of times less resistant to currents. It was almost as if the material had morphed from rubber into metal. The PI argues that countless electrons circulate around inside their honeycombs at all times, tracing the edges of each octahedron, forming internal loop currents (see attached image). In the absence of a magnetic field, those loop currents tend to stay disorderly, or flow in both clockwise and counterclockwise patterns. It’s a bit like cars driving through a roundabout in both directions at once, which cause “traffic jams” for electrons traveling in the material, thus increasing the resistance, and making the honeycomb an insulator. However, if an external electric current is applied to the honeycomb in the presence of a magnetic field aligned along a certain direction, the internal loop currents will circulate only along one direction, thus the traffic jams disappear. Consequently, electrons can speed through the quantum material, almost as if it was a metal wire. The internal loop currents are extraordinarily susceptible to external currents exceeding a critical threshold, which disrupts and eventually “melts” the loop currents”, leading to a different quantum state. This discovery offers a new paradigm for quantum technologies. 

The Nation is committed to a high-tech economy or “quantum revolution”, and urgently needs scientists who are experienced in quantum materials discovery and synthesis. This project addressed this national urgency via rigorous training of graduate and undergraduate students, who are the future human capital for technologies that drive the economy. 

Studies funded by this award have resulted in 26 publications, including one book published by Oxford University Press, several articles published in high profile journals, such as Nature, Physical Review Letters, Physical Review X, Quantum Materials, etc. This award supported four graduate students, and two of them earned their Ph.D. in Physics and are now employed at the Argonne National Laboratory.
